subNodes.conversationText: root
The body of a young man lay here, propped against a rock. His injuries looked too severe to have come from falling down the hole.
<FirstName> examined the body.

He was in his mid-twenties, maybe, and had the look of someone who spent most of his life indoors. Though good-looking, he was very thin. He wore an embroidered doublet and jerkin soiled through with blood and grime.
[Continue.]
"I didn't do it."
[Continue.]

The owner of the voice slunk out from behind the rock. It was a lanky, appalling creature with long teeth and clawed hands. It stooped as it moved. If it stood up straight, it'd be eight feet high, but it didn't seem inclined to stand up straight.
[Folk Magic] <FirstName> appraised the creature. "How did you get cursed, and what do you have to do with this body?"

The young witch knew what this thing was. Driven by greed to cross the wrong person, a hungry ghost was cursed with a disgusting form and disgusting cravings. Though not truly ghosts, a hungry ghost was dead to its old life, and part of its curse was a greatly prolonged new one.
[Continue.]
The creature waved its talons. "The woman who cursed me died, and her reasons died with her. The curse survives, and that's why I'm here."
The creature waved its talons. "The woman who cursed me died, and her reasons died with her. The curse survives, and that's why I'm here."
[Continue.]
"I'm drawn like a fly to the smell of death, and nothing smells better than the corpse of someone young."
"You eat the dead."

"I've tried it." The creature shrugged. "It wasn't pleasant. But the smell! The smell! That's what I want. I loathe it, and I love it, and most of all, I can't have it. It doesn't fill me up. It's -- nothing, air."
[Continue.]

The creature breathed in through its nose and then had a kind of fit. It crawled on its hands and knees to where the body lay and began sniffing and snuffling with great energy, looking askance at the young witch all the while, its bloodshot and jaundiced eyeballs bulging.
[Continue.]
"Turn away!" it gasped. "Don't watch me do this."
The young witch didn't listen to the creature's request.
Fascinated and disgusted, <he/she> watched the creature go about its business.
[Continue.]

The hungry ghost drew back from the corpse and vomited. Try as <he/she> might, the young witch couldn't avoid all the spray. Then the creature wiped its mouth, patted its belly, and slumped to the ground, exhausted.
[Continue,]
"Help me," it said.
"I'd help you if I could, but how?"

"A witch did this to me, a witch from long ago." For a moment, the creature's contorted face relaxed -- a result, perhaps, of a dim memory of its old life. "You are a witch, too, and easier to talk to than other witches I've met. There must be a way for you to undo this."
[Folk Magic] "This is a powerful curse, and an old one. It has deep roots. I don't think I can dispel it."
The hungry ghost wailed and gnashed its teeth.

Then <FirstName> reflected that Eldest Lady might know about such things. <He/She> told the hungry ghost <he/she> would ask her. "She might not be able, and she might not be willing. But it's worth a shot."
This appeased the creature. Its eyes glistened with gratitude. Then, with a look of fiendish glee, it threw itself on top of the corpse and resumed its strange feast.
[End.]
"Magic like that is beyond me. I've never even had a coven."
The hungry ghost wailed and gnashed its teeth.
"Why would I help you?"
The creature mused. "I saw what happened here. I saw this murder. I could tell you what happened."
"Perhaps you could -- but I'm a witch, not a constable. I'm not sure it matters to me."

The hungry ghost inhaled through its nose. "What the witches know, the kami know; and what the kami know, the accursed sometimes hear... There's blood on the arrow you carry. I can smell it. You're looking for a killer, and you haven't found the right one yet. Well, one was here."
"But how could I help you?"

"A witch did this to me, a witch from long ago." For a moment, the creature's contorted face relaxed -- a result, perhaps, of a dim memory of its old life. "You are a witch, too, and easier to talk to than other witches I've met. There must be a way for you to undo this."
"I suppose it might be useful to know that. But how could I help you?"

"A witch did this to me, a witch from long ago." For a moment, the creature's contorted face relaxed -- a result, perhaps, of a dim memory of its old life. "You are a witch, too, and easier to talk to than other witches I've met. There must be a way for you to undo this."
"You've soiled my robes with your vomit. Stitch me new ones and then we'll talk."
The hungry ghost helds up its talons. "I'm bad at threading needles."
"So I see. But why would I help you for nothing?"
The creature mused. "I saw what happened here. I saw this murder. I could tell you what happened."
<FirstName> sighed. "Very well. What do you want?"

"A witch did this to me, a witch from long ago." For a moment, the creature's contorted face relaxed -- a result, perhaps, of a dim memory of its old life. "You are a witch, too, and easier to talk to than other witches I've met. There must be a way for you to undo this."
"Well then, you've held me up long enough. I have things to do today."
The creature mused. "I saw what happened here. I saw this murder. I could tell you what happened."
"Let me put you out of your misery," said the young witch.
"My own business is urgent. I'm afraid I can't."
The creature mused. "I saw what happened here. I saw this murder. I could tell you what happened."
"Let me put you out of your misery," said the young witch.
"No!" wailed the creature. "Don't kill me, don't. As wretched and useless as this life is, I want it."
"I'm not letting you make the decision," said the young witch, readying <him/her>self for combat.
"Then I have nothing to give you."
The creature mused. "I saw what happened here. I saw this murder. I could tell you what happened."
The young witch did as <he/she> was asked.
The snuffling noises ceased, and the young witch turned back around.
[Continue.]
"I'm sorry."

The young witch's pity seemed to surprise the creature. "My suffering is very great. The smell! The smell! I loathe it, and I love it, and most of all, I can't have it. It doesn't fill me up. Nothing fills me up."
[Continue.]
"And what do you do if you can't find a young body? Kill one and let it rot?"
"No! No! It's not like that. I can't kill, not out of desire -- not myself and not anyone else. That's part of my curse. I can't really eat either."
[Continue.]

"I've tried it." The creature shrugged. "It wasn't pleasant. But the smell! The smell! That's what I want. I loathe it, and I love it, and most of all, I can't have it. It doesn't fill me up. Nothing fills me up."
"Disgusting. Let me end your sordid life."
"No!" wailed the creature. "Don't kill me, don't. As wretched and useless as this life is, I want it."
"I'm not letting you make the decision," said the young witch, readying <him/her>self for combat.
"Very well. What do you want, then?"
"The smell! The smell! That's what I want. I loathe it, and I love it, and most of all, I can't have it. It doesn't fill me up. Nothing fills me up."
[Continue.]
"What are you? Did you murder this man?"
"I'm a hungry ghost. I didn't kill him."
[Continue.]

The young witch had heard about such creatures. Driven by greed to cross the wrong person, the hungry ghost was cursed with a disgusting form and disgusting cravings. Though not truly ghosts, a hungry ghost was dead to its old life, and part of its curse was a greatly prolonged new one.
The creature did not look friendly. <FirstName> got ready to fight.
"Hold, hold! Don't hurt me."
[Folk Magic] <FirstName> appraised the creature. "How did you get cursed, and what do you have to do with this body?"
"Die, treacherous thing," said <FirstName>.
The young witch didn't attack but remained on guard.
"I'm a hungry ghost. I didn't kill him."
[Continue.]

The young witch had heard about such creatures. Driven by greed to cross the wrong person, the hungry ghost was cursed with a disgusting form and disgusting cravings. Though not truly ghosts, a hungry ghost was dead to its old life, and part of its curse was a greatly prolonged new one.
"What are you doing here?"
"I'm drawn like a fly to the smell of death, and nothing smells better than the corpse of someone young."
"I don't trust you." The young witch lunged at the hungry ghost.
"Poor creature! You have my pity. Farewell."
"What are you? Did you murder this man?"
<FirstName> backed away from the creature.
"I won't hurt you if you don't hurt me."
But the young witch knew it was dangerous to talk to monsters. <He/She> lunged at it.
[Folk Magic] "How did you get cursed, and what do you have to do with this body?"

The young witch knew what this thing was. Driven by greed to cross the wrong person, a hungry ghost was cursed with a disgusting form and disgusting cravings. Though not truly ghosts, a hungry ghost was dead to its old life, and part of its curse was a greatly prolonged new one.
The young witch didn't attack but remained on guard.
"What are you? Did you murder this man?"
<FirstName> left the body alone.
"I didn't do it."
